file_metadata.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]
file_metadata.title: Revealing non-neural information structures in aneural biological tissues via functional connectivity

chunks.text: A central challenge in biology is understanding information integration in tissues for functions like morphogenesis and wound healing. Information-theoretic approaches, while successful in neuroscience, have limited application in other tissues. This study uses Ca2+ dynamics to analyze information structure in non-neural tissues, applying methods from neuroscience to epidermal organoids.
chunks.chunk_summary: Information-theoretic approaches are applied to non-neural tissues to understand information integration using Ca2+ dynamics.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: GCaMP6s was expressed in Xenopus laevis epidermal organoids, and calcium activity was imaged before and after injury. Functional connectivity (FC) networks were constructed using mutual information between cells. Analysis of network properties revealed potential evidence for non-random connectivity, high-degree hubs, and mesoscale community structure with spatial clustering.
chunks.chunk_summary: FC networks constructed from Ca2+ imaging data revealed non-random connectivity and mesoscale community structure in Xenopus epidermal organoids.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: The organoid networks retained non-random features after injury, displaying long-range correlations and non-trivial clustering. This suggests increased integration after injury and potential cellular coordination. The computational approach is generalizable to any tissue and fluorescent signal, offering a bridge between neuroscience and basal information processing.
chunks.chunk_summary: Organoid networks showed increased integration and non-trivial clustering after injury, suggesting cellular coordination.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: Information processing is crucial for biological function, especially in neuronal tissues where information-theoretic approaches are widely used. However, these approaches have limited application in non-neural tissues despite the importance of communication in multicellular life. This study aims to develop a universally applicable approach to quantify tissue function and behavior using information theory.
chunks.chunk_summary: Information-theoretic approaches, while prevalent in neuroscience, need broader application in understanding non-neural tissue function.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: Multicellular systems require coordinated cell actions for processes like development, wound healing, and regeneration. Traditional techniques focus on single-element activation, but capturing longer spatiotemporal scales is crucial for understanding collective behavior. Functional connectivity (FC) networks offer a framework for identifying connections and information flow at these scales.
chunks.chunk_summary: FC networks provide a framework for understanding collective behavior in multicellular systems by capturing longer spatiotemporal scales.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: FC networks, based on statistical correlations, reveal long-range temporal correlations not captured by anatomical connectivity maps. Ca2+, a ubiquitous signaling molecule, can track physiological responses and information flow. Fluorescent Ca2+ reporters are widely used in neuroscience, and Ca2+ regulates epithelium healing. This study demonstrates long-range correlations via FC networks, suggesting memory or long-range coordination in wound healing.
chunks.chunk_summary: FC networks, using Ca2+ signaling, can reveal long-range correlations and potential memory or coordination in wound healing.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: GCaMP6s and Notch ICD mRNA were injected into Xenopus laevis embryos at the 4-cell stage. Animal caps were excised and cultured to form epidermal organoids. Calcium imaging was performed 7 days post-fertilization, capturing basal activity and response to a puncture wound. Kymographs revealed systemic calcium activation and resolution after injury, as well as less frequent long-range flashes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Calcium imaging of Xenopus epidermal organoids revealed systemic activation after injury and long-range flashes.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: Global calcium signal analysis showed a sharp increase after puncture. Image registration and cell segmentation were performed using ANTs and Cellpose. Time series of calcium readings were extracted for each cell. Global signal regression (GSR) and local conditional entropy rate transformation were applied to remove artifacts and emphasize signal changes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Image processing and data analysis techniques were applied to extract and refine calcium time series data from organoids.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: FC networks were constructed using mutual information between cells, representing signaling dynamics. Analysis of these networks aimed to understand information structure in the epidermis and its response to injury.
chunks.chunk_summary: FC networks were constructed to analyze information structure and response to injury in epidermal tissue.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: Edge time series of post-puncture networks showed higher correlations initially, supported by root sum square (RSS) amplitudes. Pre-puncture RSS amplitudes lacked a consistent trend. This suggests increased integration after injury, potentially due to highly correlated Ca2+ signals. Some edge time series displayed high-amplitude co-fluctuations (events), hinting at a complex interaction structure.
chunks.chunk_summary: Post-puncture networks showed increased initial correlations, suggesting increased integration after injury, and some displayed high-amplitude co-fluctuations.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: Network analysis revealed heavier tail degree distributions and higher maximum degrees compared to Erdős Rènyi random graph null models. This suggests non-randomness and the presence of hub nodes. Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests showed significant differences between pre- and post-puncture distributions, except for one organoid with fewer nodes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Network analysis revealed non-random topology with hub nodes and significant differences between pre- and post-puncture distributions.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: Spearman correlation analysis showed a negative correlation between functional connection magnitude and spatial distance, except for two post-puncture networks. This indicates that closer cells have more coordinated signaling, consistent with known signaling mechanisms. Post-puncture coefficients were less negative, suggesting increased long-range connections.
chunks.chunk_summary: Functional connection strength negatively correlated with spatial distance, with potential increase in long-range connections post-puncture.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: Community detection using multi-resolution consensus clustering revealed modular structure. Some communities were spatially clustered, while others were dispersed. Within-module distance distributions showed peaks at small distances but extended to larger distances, suggesting both spatial and non-spatial modularity. Post-puncture networks had nodes connected to a higher fraction of modules, indicating increased integration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Community detection revealed both spatially clustered and dispersed modules, with increased inter-module connectivity post-puncture.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: This study demonstrated an information-theoretic approach for analyzing functional connectivity in a non-neural organoid system. The approach revealed non-random FC network structure with heavy-tail degree distributions and high-amplitude co-fluctuations. Functional connection correlated negatively with distance, but long-range connections were also present, with spatially diverse communities.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study revealed non-random FC network structure with distance-dependent connectivity and spatially diverse communities in a non-neural system.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: The cause of the observed modules remains unclear, potentially related to cell types or underlying signals. The FC networks retained key characteristics after injury but showed increased integration post-puncture, suggesting dynamic restructuring. Limitations include small sample size, short time series, and challenges in cell segmentation and image registration due to perturbation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Limitations include small sample size and technical challenges, but the study suggests dynamic restructuring of FC networks after injury.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: Future work should explore different dependency measures, effective connectivity, and higher-order interactions. The chosen null model, while classic, may not capture all physical effects. Further research should consider appropriate null models and investigate the biological significance of network changes, including their role in healing and response to different injury types.
chunks.chunk_summary: Future work should explore alternative methods and null models to further investigate the biological significance of observed network changes.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: The study used Xenopus laevis embryos, injected with GCaMP6s and Notch ICD mRNA. Animal caps were excised and cultured to form epidermal organoids. Calcium imaging was performed at 1 frame/5 seconds for 20 minutes before and after a puncture wound. Videos were preprocessed using ANTs for image registration and Cellpose for cell segmentation.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study involved calcium imaging of Xenopus epidermal organoids before and after a puncture wound, followed by image processing.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]

chunks.text: Time series data were extracted for each cell, and global signal regression (GSR) and local conditional entropy rate transformation were applied. Functional connectivity (FC) networks were constructed using mutual information. Network analysis included degree distribution, spatial embedding, and community detection using multi-resolution consensus clustering.
chunks.chunk_summary: Data analysis included GSR, entropy rate transformation, FC network construction, and network analysis.
chunks.authors: ["Douglas Blackiston", "Hannah Dromniak", "Caitlin Grasso", "Thomas F. Varley", "Bongard G. Michael Levin", "Krishna Kannan Srinivasan", "Olaf Sporns"]
